Carbon black intercalation compound as catalyst for unprecedent phase-transfer-catalyzed nucleophilic substitution (SN2) in water Arianna Melillo Conceptualization Methodology Investigation a Aida Kiani Investigation b Rosaria Schettini Conceptualization Methodology Validation Supervision Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Maria Rosaria Acocella Conceptualization Methodology Validation Supervision Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing b ⁎ a Ecole Normale Superiere de Paris, PSL 45 rue d'Ulm 75230 Paris cedex 05, France Ecole Normale Superiere de Paris PSL 45 rue d'Ulm 75230 Paris cedex 05 France aEcole Normale Superiere de Paris, PSL 45 rue d'Ulm 75230 Paris cedex 05, France b Department of Chemistry and Biology “A. Zambelli”, University of Salerno Via Giovanni Paolo II, 84084, Fisciano (Sa), Italy Department of Chemistry and Biology “A. Zambelli” University of Salerno Via Giovanni Paolo II Fisciano (Sa) 84084 Italy bDepartment of Chemistry and Biology “A. Zambelli”, University of Salerno Via Giovanni Paolo II, 84084, Fisciano (Sa), Italy ⁎ Corresponding authors. Carbon black intercalation compound was used for the first time as a heterogeneous phase-transfer-catalyst for SN2 type reaction of NaSCN with 4-nitrobenzyl bromide. The reaction proceeds in the presence of 5 mol% of catalyst with high efficiency in a liquid-liquid biphasic system (CHCl3/H2O), providing 98% conversion after only 4 h. Furthermore, an unprecedent efficient nucleophilic substitution was reported in water solution in the presence of the new catalyst, providing 95% yield in 8 h. The reaction is green, and the heterogeneous catalyst can be recovered and recycled without losing efficiency. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phase transfer catalyst Nucleophilic substitution Carbon black Green procedure Intercalation compounds Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Graphite intercalation compounds have been extensively studied for their interesting and useful properties and applications. They have been used as highly conductive materials [1–3], electrodes in batteries [4–8], for storage of hydrogen [9–11], and as catalysts for organic synthesis [12–15]. Although the crystalline structure of graphite is usually saved by introducing small ions that provide high 3D long-range order, with a small distance between the graphene sheets, the formation of highly ordered graphite oxide intercalation compounds in the presence of bulky cation has also been reported [16]. Specifically, high 3D order has been obtained by intercalating ammonium ions containing two long alkyl tails. Just recently, also the ability of oxidized Carbon black (oCB) to form ordered intercalation compounds in the presence of di-(hydrogenated tallow)-dimethylammonium chloride (2HT) was reported for the first time [17]. The unexpected formation of ordered intercalate crystalline structure from highly disordered oxidized Carbon black (oCB) was justified by the replacement of metal ions with ammonium ions on graphitic layers, whose ionically bonded hydrocarbon chains arrange in the hexagonal rotator phase. The resulting decorated small graphene layers self-assemble in an ordered intercalate crystalline structure with long tails perpendicular to the graphitic layers. This is possible because, although CB and oCB are amorphous powders, they are composed of a disordered spatial arrangement of graphene and graphene oxide layers. While the use of graphite intercalation compounds as catalysts for some organic reactions was already reported, to the best of our knowledge, there are no examples of reactions catalyzed by carbon black intercalation compounds. Considering the predominant use of ammonium salts in phase-transfer catalysis, we decided to evaluate the ability of the novel carbon black intercalated compound with the quaternary ammonium salt (2HT) as a phase-transfer catalyst. It has to be noted that if the use of quaternary ammonium salts is interesting due to their well-known catalytic properties as phase-transfer catalysts, their efficiency and selectivity could be enhanced by their intercalation into carbon black [18]. The great interest in phase-transfer catalysis (PTC) is due to its wide application in academia and industrial research. Since the pioneering studies on phase-transfer reactions, this research field has been recognized as an attractive area for green sustainable chemistry: benefits are particularly evident in oxidation chemistry [19,20] and asymmetric transformations [21,22]. Mainly, the advantages of phase-transfer catalysis are linked to mild reaction conditions, simplicity of experimental procedures, and the use of inexpensive and environmentally friendly reagents and solvents [23]. Generally, reactions occur in heterogeneous conditions at the interface of two immiscible phases. The role of a phase-transfer catalyst is to facilitate the migration of a reactant from one phase (the aqueous layer) to the other where the reaction occurs (the organic layer) [19,20]. Even if the most used phase-transfer catalysts are organic cations, such as ammonium or phosphonium salts, due to their relatively good stability, catalytic efficiency, and lipophilicity [24–26] also macrocyclic complexing agents like crown ethers [27], calixarenes [28], cyclodextrins [29], and more recently cyclic peptoids have been widely exploited [30,31]. Just lately, amphiphilic carbon-dots were used for a variety of organic transformations like carbon–carbon bond formation, oxidation, reduction, multiplestep synthesis in polar-nonpolar reaction media without additives and PTC, [32–34] but to the best of our knowledge, no examples of SN2 type reaction have been reported. We present here the synthesis, characterization, and catalytic performance of this novel PTC catalyst based on carbon intercalation compounds in a nucleophilic substitution reaction performed both in a biphasic (liquid-liquid) system and, most interestingly, in water. The new catalyst assures high conversion (up to 98%) and, being heterogenous, the possibility to be recovered and recycled with negligible efficiency reduction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation and characterization of adducts of oxidized Carbon black with 2HT (di-(hydrogenated tallow)-dimethylammonium bromide) oCB/2HT adduct has been prepared starting from the oCB sample with a 0.58 O/C ratio. 200 mg of oCB powders were dispersed in 0.05 M NaOH solution (40 mL), and 100 mL of 2HT aqueous solution (2 mg mL−1) was added in this dispersion, and the reaction mixture was stirred at 60°C for 1 h. The black slurry was centrifuged at 10 000 rpm for 15 min, and the precipitate was washed with deionized water and dried at 60°C for 12 h in an oven. 2.2 General procedure for the nucleophilic substitution using oCB/2HT as PTC in water To a solution of 4-nitrobenzyl bromide (21.5 mg, 0.10 mmol) in H2O (0.25 M, 0.200 mL), containing 5 mol% of the catalyst, a 0.75 M aqueous solution of thiocyanate salt (0.15 mmol) was added, and the resulting mixture was stirred until total conversion unless otherwise mentioned. The reaction was monitored by TLC. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc, the solvent was removed in a vacuum, and the resulting residue was analyzed by 1H-NMR to measure the conversion percentage. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX 400 (1H at 400.13 MHz). Chemical shifts (δ) are reported in ppm relative to the residual solvent peak (CHCl3, δ = 7.26), and the following abbreviations designate the multiplicity of each signal: s, singlet; d, doublet. Reactions were monitored by analytical thin layer chromatography (TLC) on precoated silica gel plates (0.25 mm) and visualized by UV light. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of oCB/2HT Commercial Carbon Black sample, exhibiting a BET surface area of 130 m2/g, has been oxidized by the Hummers procedure, [35] providing 0.58 as O/C weight ratio as evaluated by elemental analysis. The synthesis and characterization of oCB are fully reported in the supporting information. oCB/2HT has been prepared starting from oCB and 2HT in alkaline aqueous dispersion according to the procedure reported in Section 2.1. X-ray diffraction patterns of 2HT (a), oCB (b), and oCB/2HT adduct (c) are shown in Fig. 1 . The 001, 003, and 005 reflections of the oCB/2HT intercalate structure, and the disappearance of 2HT diffraction peaks indicate the adduct formation. Furthermore, a broad diffraction peak centered at d=0.42 nm appears due to the formation of hexagonal hydrocarbon rotator order already observed with surfactants with long alkyl chains with graphene oxide [16,17]. The FTIR spectrum of oCB/2HT has been compared with the starting oCB and 2HT salt in the range of 4000-400 cm−1 (Fig. 2 A). The spectrum shows that many vibrational peaks of 2HT are clearly present in oCB/2HT. Specifically, the bands related to the 2HT alkyl chains in the range 2953-2842 and the peaks at 719 and 614 cm−1 are both observable in the intercalation compound. Furthermore, the peak at 1473 cm−1 is red-shifted to 1462 cm−1 , possibly due to the reduced confinement of 2HT in the oCB compounds. It is worth noting that alkaline treatment followed by adding salt changes the oCB spectrum significantly. In particular, the defined peaks in the range 1300-900 cm−1 corresponding to ethers, alcohols, carboxylic groups, and sulfonic groups vibrations [36] disappear, and a shift of carboxyl group frequency from 1715 cm−1 in oCB to 1640 cm−1 in oCB/2HT, resulting in carboxylate group formation is detected. TGA scans of oCB, 2HT and oCB/2HT are shown in Fig. 2B. It is apparent that the degradation of 2HT, which for the salt occurs around 200°C, for oCB/2HT arises at a higher temperature, centered around 300°C, showing higher thermal stability. Considering the residue at 800°C, the 2HT uptake is calculated to be 12 wt%. The oCB/2HT, as obtained, was investigated as a possible heterogeneous phase-transfer catalyst for the SN2 reaction of MSCN with 4-nitrobenzyl bromide, chosen as the model reaction (Scheme 1 ). 3.2 Catalytic ability of oCB/2HT as PTC in a biphasic system First, the catalytic ability of oCB/2HT in the nucleophilic substitution was evaluated in a liquid-liquid biphasic system (CHCl3/H2O) using NaSCN as a nucleophile. All reactions were carried out with 5 mol% of catalyst loading, were monitored chromatographically, and were analyzed by 1H-NMR determining the conversion percentage. To ensure the presence of 5 mol% of the intercalated ammonium ion, the functionalization degree of oCB/2HT was considered. In the same conditions, oCB and 2HT were evaluated separately, Table 1 (entries 1 and 2). In the presence of oxidized Carbon black (oCB), the reaction did not proceed significantly, giving just 8% of conversion after 24 h (Table 1, entry 1), while the quaternary ammonium salt 2HT afforded the product 89% of conversion after 24 h (Table 1, entry 2). Surprisingly, the intercalated compound oCB/2HT catalyzed the substitution reaction more efficiently than the quaternary ammonium salt 2HT (Table 1, entry 3 vs. entry 2), giving the substitution adduct in 98% of conversion after only 4 h. It has to be noted that the activity of oCB/2HT is comparable to that observed in the presence of the tetraalkylammonium salt (Table 1, entry 3 vs. entry 7), commonly used as a phase-transfer catalyst [24]. Encouraged by this result, we decided to screen the reaction parameters starting with the catalyst's loading. A high conversion was also reached by reducing the amount of catalyst to 1 mol%, although with a longer reaction time (Table 1, entry 4). Further reducing the catalyst loading up to 0.1 mol%, a substantial decrease in the efficiency was observed (Table 1, entry 5). To verify the scope of the procedure, an additional experiment was performed in the presence of KSCN, and interestingly, the reaction proceeded again with high conversion >98% in 5.5h (Table 1, entry 6). With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, we investigated the effect of solvents (Table 2 ). All reactions were stopped after 4 h to compare the percentage of conversion by 1H-NMR. Although the reaction in the presence of ethyl acetate provides an acceptable conversion, it is clear from all entries that the change of polarity of the solvent deeply affects the efficiency of the reaction, with chloroform being the best choice. 3.3 Catalytic ability of oCB/2HT in water Considering the evolving attitudes about environmental issues, the research field of green chemistry has been receiving a lot of attention. In particular, organic synthesis laboratories and pharmaceutical industries gave much more attention to green chemical processes. Several solvent selection guides were published in the literature to reduce the use of hazardous solvents [37,38]. Inspired by the result obtained with a recommended solvent as AcOEt (Table 2, entry 3) and considering that water is the greenest solvent, we decided to test our reaction without any organic solvent. Water is an inexpensive, renewable source for safe industrial processes and environmental concerns [39,40]. Although nucleophilic substitution is a widely used transformation for the formation of C-C or C-X (X=heteratom) bonds, water is rarely used as the reaction medium due to the poor solubility of organic substrates [41,42]. Here we show, for the first time, the ability of oCB/2HT to catalyze the reaction even in water solution, providing high conversion in a reasonable time in the presence of NaSCN as well as KSCN As reported in Table 3 , the reaction in the presence of NaSCN provides the product in 95% conversion in 8h, while in the presence of KSCN, the same reaction proceeds with 88% in 9h (Table 3, entries 1 and 2). It is worth noting that the same reaction performed with 2HT requires 24 h to reach up to 89% yield, showing again the better efficiency of oCB/2HT. The influence of the intercalation compound on reaction rate is shown in Fig. 3 , as yield of product versus reaction time. This phase-transfer reaction obeyed pseudo-first-order kinetic as confirmed by our experimental data [30,43]. It is evident that the reaction rate increases already after 2h of reaction, with the maximum rise after 8 h, providing 95% and 63% yield in the presence of oCB/2HT and 2HT, respectively [44]. The increased rate observed for oCB/2HT could be explained by considering the enhancement of the efficiency of 2HT for its intercalation into oxidized Carbon black [18]. To assess the scope of the procedure, a variety of alkylating agents was reacted with NaSCN under the optimized conditions in water and the results are summarized in Table 4 . As expected, benzyl bromides with electron-withdrawing or electron-donor substituents gave the same results in terms of conversion as their parents without substitution (Entry 1,3, and 4 vs entry 2 Table 4). With bromoalkene as the substrate (entry 5, Table 4), the reaction did not proceed at all even after a longer reaction time (24 h). Finally, the possibility of recycling our catalyst was investigated using the addition of NaSCN to 4-nitrobenzyl bromide as model reaction: all reactions were stopped after 8h, and an extraction recovered the product with ethyl acetate and the catalyst from the aqueous layer. An initial decrease of 7% was observed after the first run, while the yield was quite stable after the second one, (Fig. 4 ) showing interesting stability of the catalyst that, being heterogeneous, can be recovered and recycled [45]. Taking into account the ability of oCB/2HT to catalyze the reaction even in water solution, and to be recovered and recycled without substantial loss of efficiency, a possible catalytic mechanism has been hypothesized (Scheme 2 ). As described in Sections 2.1 and 3.1, the catalyst is formed by a cation exchange reaction after basification of the starting oCB, to provide ordered intercalated compounds with alkyl chains perpendicular to the graphitic planes. By adding NaSCN solution to the catalyst and reagent mixture, a further cation exchange could possibly occur to afford the 2HT/SCN ionic pair and restore the sodium intercalation compound of oCB. Then thiocyanate could attack the benzyl position to furnish the SN2 type substitution product, and 2HT/Br can be formed and react with the sodium intercalation compound, to provide the catalyst once again. (oCB/2HT). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a nucleophilic substitution efficiently catalyzed by an intercalated carbon black compound. The reaction can be performed in a biphasic system and water solution, representing an important goal in PTC. This novel application paves the way to asymmetric phase-transfer reactions using this new typology of catalyst for sustainable processes. 4 Conclusion This contribution represents an unprecedent example of SN2 type reaction catalyzed by a new intercalated carbon compound. The reaction of NaSCN with 4-nitrobenzyl bromide was performed in a liquid-liquid biphasic system in the presence of 5 mol% of oCB/2HT, providing 98% conversion after only 4 h. Furthermore, for the first time, an efficient nucleophilic substitution in water solution was shown here, providing the desired product in the presence of oCB/2HT in 95% conversion after 8 h. Being heterogeneous, the catalyst can be easily recovered and recycled with negligible efficiency reduction. The high efficiency of this catalyst could find applications not only in academic laboratories but also for green industrial applications. Considering the potential of this heterogeneous catalyst, further studies on other organic reactions are in progress in our laboratories and will be reported in due course. coredata.dc:description: Carbon black intercalation compound was used for the first time as a heterogeneous phase-transfer-catalyst for SN2 type reaction of NaSCN with 4-nitrobenzyl bromide. The reaction proceeds in the presence of 5 mol% of catalyst with high efficiency in a liquid-liquid biphasic system (CHCl3/H2O), providing 98% conversion after only 4 h. Furthermore, an unprecedent efficient nucleophilic substitution was reported in water solution in the presence of the new catalyst, providing 95% yield in 8 h. The reaction is green, and the heterogeneous catalyst can be recovered and recycled without losing efficiency.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Carbon black intercalation compound as catalyst for unprecedent phase-transfer-catalyzed nucleophilic substitution (SN2) in water
